[FINDING]
Category: mathematical_error
Severity: critical
Line: 71
Quote: "The R-square measure of correlation between two sets of data is the same as the cosine of the angle between them when presented as vectors in N-dimensional space"
Issue: This is incorrect. The correlation coefficient R (not R²) equals the cosine of the angle between centered vectors. R² would be cos²(θ), not cos(θ).
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: mathematical_error
Severity: critical
Line: 75
Quote: "Grant a factor correlated with an outcome, which we represent with two vectors at an angle theta, the inverse cosine equal the R-squared."
Issue: This contradicts line 71 and is also incorrect. The angle θ = arccos(R), not arccos(R²). The inverse cosine equals the correlation coefficient R, not R-squared.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: logical_flaw
Severity: major
Line: 61
Quote: "the average wealth of the +4SD intelligence population is 1SD higher than the 3SD intelligence people"
Issue: This contradicts the earlier setup where intelligence and conscientiousness were said to be "equally important" to wealth. If both factors contribute equally and independently, a 1SD difference in one factor should yield 0.5SD difference in outcome, not 1SD.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: logical_flaw
Severity: major
Line: 59
Quote: "with 10 people at +4SD, you wouldn't expect any of them to be +2SD in conscientiousness"
Issue: This reasoning is flawed. If the factors are truly independent as stipulated, each person has the same probability of being +2SD in conscientiousness regardless of the population size at their intelligence level.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: mathematical_error
Severity: major
Line: 99
Quote: "Another intuitive dividend is that this makes it clear why you can by R-squared to move between z-scores of correlated normal variables"
Issue: You multiply by R (the correlation coefficient), not R², to convert z-scores between correlated normal variables. The expected z-score of Y given X is R times the z-score of X.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: clarity_issue
Severity: minor
Line: 23
Quote: "comparing the speed of a ball out of a baseball pitchers hand compared to its speed crossing crossing the plate"
Issue: Redundant use of "comparing" and "compared", and duplicate word "crossing".
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: missing_content
Severity: minor
Line: 83
Quote: "There may be spread betting or portfolio scenarios where this factor comes into play - perhaps instead of funding AMF to diminishing returns when its marginal effectiveness dips below charity #2, we should be willing to spread funds sooner.(6)"
Issue: Footnote 6 referenced here appears to be about R² and z-scores (line 99), not about portfolio allocation strategies. The relevant footnote appears to be missing.
[/FINDING]
